item.title: [MY21] Questor
item.author: MY21
item.description: Avoid African Barrick Gold until recovery takes root: Shares in African Barrick Gold rose 4.7% to 214.4p after brokers made reassuring noises about the miner’s ability to turn round its struggling mines. The miner’s third quarter results, which came out on October 23, showed signs of improvement. Gold production increased to about 190,986 ounces in the three months ended September - up 16% on the same period last year. The company also cut the costs of production by 13% on the same stage last year, to $1,098 per ounce. African Barrick said third quarter revenue was up 9% to $241 million, as the increased output more than offset lower gold prices. The cash position is also improving marginally, with total cash up $17 million to $287 million at September 30, leaving an estimate for net cash of $145 million once the $142 million loan facility is subtracted. The company had cash of $401 million at the end of June last year. However, Questor would still be reluctant to jump back into this high-cost gold miner. The market expects pretax profits of $149.4 million this year on revenue of $931.1 million, giving earnings per share of 25.2c (15.6p). African Barrick is a higher cost operator and, given the weaker prices in nearly all commodities this year, it is at risk from gold falling lower. African Barrick Gold at 214.4p+9.4p Questor Says ‘Avoid’

item.title: [sinnerthesaint] Commendation from Minister of State
item.author: sinnerthesaint
item.description:
Tarime — MINISTER of State in the Vice-President's Office ( Environment) Dr Binilith Mahenge, has commended North Mara Gold Mine for conforming to the highest environmental protection standards.
"I am impressed to see that North Mara Gold Mine has heavily invested in environmental programmes and I believe other mines will take a leaf," Dr Mahenge said here over the weekend after spending several hours inspecting various environmental programmes by the mine.
Among other things, he was shown a Tailings Storage Facility (TSF), a modern multimillion shilling water treatment plant which recycles waste water.
A few years back the mine was in the spotlight after allegedly polluting River Tigithe, one of the major sources of water for the surrounding villages.
The mine was now spending 1.5 million US dollars (over 2.5bn/-) on environmental programmes each year, according to its General Manager, Mr Gary Chapman. Dr Mahenge said the government needed investments that strictly adhered to acceptable environmental standards.
He was accompanied by several senior officials from the National Environment Management Council (NEMC), including Dr Robert Ntakamulenga, the Director of Compliance and Enforcement at NECM, and Mr Manchare Heche, a senior legal officer from NEMC.
The minister was shown two modern public primary schools which had been built with support from the mine at a cost of over 3bn/-. He also called on the mine to support artisanal miners living in the villages around the mine.
Dr Mahenge also witnessed dozens of youth who intruded in one of the gold mine's pits to steal gold sand at high risk to the environment. The intruders were armed with sharp objects which appeared to be machetes.
Frequent intrusions by mostly young men have continued to be one of the critical problems disturbing operations at the mine, which is operated by African Barrick Gold (ABG).

item.title: [sinnerthesaint] timeframe
item.author: sinnerthesaint
item.description:
"I think it's all about the timeframe / timespans you trade"
Joeysheedy, I agree that the factor above has strong relevance. When I said you have to be in the market all the time, I was indeed referring to daytrading and I meant trading not price-watching - but most importantly I was referring to the casino-house principles. If you are just price watching then yes, what's the point, you might as well be having a game of tennis - it can even be counter productive as you have found out the hard way. Analysis->Strategy->Plan->Execute and repeat - That should take all the time you have in a trading-day, no time for watching prices and getting psychological side-effects. Volume of trading is important because daily volatility only gives you tight margins when compared to weeklies and monthlies and you don't want to throw all your eggs in one basket either. Of course, I'm talking about your own tried and tested strategies here, you cannot wedge your experimental ones in here otherwise you'd just be feeding those on commissions. All the best.

item.title: [joeysheedy] sinnerthesaint
item.author: joeysheedy
item.description: I think it's all about the timeframe / timespans you trade. In my first years, I was on top of the market morning and night etc. But for some reason, watching the markets made me change my mind too often, to my accounts demise. So I changed strategy. Decided I would review each financial instrument one a weekend. Go with weekly charts and not watch markets daily, but do as you said, on a weekly basis. Have to say, it completely reversed my fortunes. Never looked back. So, imo, your psychology probably determines best method. Mine works for me. Yours works for you. So many different ways to view,and enter market successfully. For me, this takes away daily emotion. Analyse, spot entry and target, select best value stop position, and let market crack on. If your method is not working, sometimes you don't need to change it. You might just need to find timeframe that suits personality. Eg for me, watching a market can make me change mind. I eliminated that, kept methodology and risk management same, and as they say, the rest is history.

item.title: [sinnerthesaint] RE: seriously
item.author: sinnerthesaint
item.description:
"It is also possible, I understand, to take a long term approach with trading 'tools' "
I'm sure there's a lot of material on the internet and in books which can give you a better insight with the above. However, fwiw, from my experience, you need different mindset for 'trading' and 'investing long term'.
For investing long term, you need the 'one' strategy. Once you know the strategy you want to use, all your work then goes into the research, analysis, risk management and decisions to feed your one strategy. And this is proven to work in big corporates as well as patient and diligent investors - I've done well with that too.
There is no real need for technical tools but it can give you an insight into how the stock price behaved in history [so your observations in the chart will all be in hindsight] - In this way you can monitor your stock price is behaving 'rationally' during the term you hold it. In my own experience, I believe that you shouldn't use it to make long term decisions however.
When you are trading short term, you cannot just develop one strategy and use it your whole life. You have to regularly come up with new ones all the time. By the time the strategy is popularly known in the market, it is time to use a different one. You use the same technical tools but for different reasons. One common mistakes that new traders do, is they try to make money by predicting future share price using TA. It cannot do that despite the many youtube videos claiming otherwise and some 'traders' on these boards - no matter what the chart 'tells' you, the price can go down or up, there's no certainty. You have to use it in a way so that it gives you a higher probability of making good bets in your long or short positions in the long run and minimise the money lost when your bets turn out to be bad ... as part of a strategy where you have risk and money management. So in effect you are creating your own casino house in the market where the odds of you winning is at least 51 to 49%. So in this way making 49 bad calls is not a problem. One thing, I will add is that you cannot be a part time trader ... you have to be active from the moment the market open and then after it closes you plan your trades for the next day, otherwise it just becomes an expensive 'lessons learnt' session.

item.title: [Beej248] RE: seriously
item.author: Beej248
item.description:
What's the rush?!... Dangerous to think you'll always be right, which is required for the strategy you suggest. My strategy is very simple (and there's no shame to admit that) - to simply acquire a diversified portfolio of real assets for as low a price as possible. Always in, initially, with a small percentage of the position I might eventually hold and with every position making up a small portion of the total portfolio. I have considered gold. I have considered the rest of the market. I have considered cash, bonds and real estate. My honest answer, and we must be honest, is that I don't really know - I don't think anyone does. I do know, however, that at the current share price here, I can buy these assets at a discount.
My goal is not to obtain the maximum return or to minimise opportunity costs as yours is. With regards to investment it is to build, over time, a portfolio of investments that one day (I certainly hope) will be realised for a sum that I can live off for retirement. Its working well so far by the way and has worked very well for many, many thousands in the past.
Now my real goals...these are something else entirely, for what do we really value in this life after all? Capital appreciation? Opportunity costs avoided? Perfect market timing? Personally, I value my family, my friends, my good health and happiness far more than any of the above and accordingly, I shall 'invest' most of my time there. Don't forget...opportunity costs are not only financial.
The definition of a 'real' investor, for the record, is one who commits capital with the hope of financial gain in the future. Interpret that how you will but if you are honest with yourself you will see that it is a pluralistic definition with many possible embodiments. As with everything else there are many paths to the destination and we must consider and respect others lest we fall victim to the inevitably myopic nature of our own. I wish you the best of luck anyway, I hope you continue to be right and become enormously wealthy. Have a good evening for now!
